advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #3 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, Victor tried to convince future IBM PC buyers that the Victor 9000 hardware technology was much more advanced than that of its competitor. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones for this picture.</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. ADVERT (1990)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this U.K. advert, the Amiga 1500 was sold at £1149.99 with a colour monitor, 4 games (Battle Chess, Sim City, Populous, Battle of Britain) and the home business suite Platinium Works. <br><br> The Amiga 500 was also sold at £399.99<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pelikonepeijoonit.net">The Arctic Computer & Console Museum</a></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><i>Texas Instruments home computer, simply unbeatable</i> <br><br> Notice that the man seems not to feel at ease with a computer keyboard and still doesn't use the right finger...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Charles da Silva</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (MAY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing pret-a-porter" <br><br> "Casio FX-702P : pocket Basic" <br><br> "Casio, it counts"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">Soichiro Oga</a> for this picture !</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (DEC. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OEMS WANTED</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (STUPID !)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dated august 1982<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1985?)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Power 3000 released in the USA.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://hem.passagen.se/clab/adam/lambda/" target="_blank">Adam's Lambda 8300 page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, APRIL 1987</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computer World magazine.<br> Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> It's an extraordinarily powerful machine which offers word-processing, spreadsheet, and a set of time and data-management tools in a single, highly porlable package.<br> At £199.95. the Z88 is supplied with 32K resident RAM. Extra 32K costs under £20, extra 128K under £50!<br> And heavy users Will be able to expand the RAM to an astonishing 3 Mbytes, using plug-in RAM cartridges.<br> For printing text or data, the Z88 connects direcly to most popular RS232 compatible printers, while for permanent storage the Z88 employs removable solid state EPROM cartridges - no tape to break, no delicate disc to damage.<br> Though the Z88 is a powerful, full facility, self-contained computer, it also acts as an extension of an office micro, connecting directly to allow exchange of text or data.<br> For every personal computer user, the Z88 offers a comprehensive specification in a package of unparalleled portability.</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #4(1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The users featured in the ad said:<br><br> (left) <i>Programming is a snap! I'm halfway through Apple's BASIC manual and already I've programmed my own Star Wars game.</i><br><br> ...with half of the universe<br><br> (middle) <i>Those math programs I wrote last week - I just rewrote them using Apple's mini assembler and got them to run a hundred time faster.</i><br><br> Of course, it's very easy for a newbie programmer to program maths assembly routines with a microprocessor which only knows how to add and subtract integer values.<br><br> (right)<i>Apple's smart peripherals make expansion easy. Just plug'em it and you are ready to run. I've already added two disks, a printer and a communication card.</i></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT(1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.spies.com/~aek/orphanage.html" target="_blank">The Minicomputer Orphanage</a> website</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH POSTER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Poster in a 1982 english computer show.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (NOV. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Same offer and same sale prices as in December 1985</blockquote>

computer.description:
The 99/8 was intended as an upmarket companion to the TI 99/4A . Something like a small business computer. However, at TI they didn't think it would generate any income, so it was never released.
It has built-in features which were optional in the 4A : The speech synthesiser and the Pascal UCSD ROM card. It is a prototype computer and was never marketed.
_______________________
Very interesting information from CC Clarke
As a young electronic technician at TI, I labored in the "trenches" during the Home Computer Wars of the early eighties. It was brutal. Our 99/4A was technologically superior to the Comodore 64, but was marketed against the VIC 20 in price. The 99/8 (codenamed: Roadrunner) was supposed to remedy that situation. It was more advanced, cheaper to produce, (the bottom line was ALWAYs the decisive factor in corporate decision-making) and used the existing TI HexBus interface, touted as the emerging interface standard at TI. Unfortunately, TI got a very bloody nose when it voluntarily recalled thousands of 99/4A AC transformers due to a perceived fusing issue.
Thousands of 99/8s were built and warehoused (before being destroyed) after it was discovered they couldn't meet FCC EMI specs without expensive design changes. In 1982/83, TI was losing more money in their Lubbock Consumer Products Division than they could justify. and the 99/8's problems made it cheaper to bury than bring to market. A few escaped and are considered collector's items.

emulator.description: Emulates all of the TI-99 versions, including the Geneve card
emulator.name: Mess emulator

emulator.description: Open Source & freeware TI-99/4A emulator for Windows 9x
emulator.name: Classic99

emulator.description: Win994a is a TI-99/4A simulator written by Cory Burr that installs and runs in Windows
emulator.name: Win994a

emulator.description: MacV9T9 is a TI99 emulator for the Macintosh
emulator.name: MacV9T9 official homepage

computer.graphics: 64 x 48 (with 4x4 graphic symbols), 256 x 128 (16 colors), 256 x 192 (16 colors)
computer.name: Computer 99/8
computer.ports: Tape, RGB video out (DIN), Joystick, HexBus connector, Expansion port (16 bits), Cartridge slot (GROM port)
computer.ram: 64 kb (up to 15Mb !)61 kb free with Basic
